title: Qué significa gulag
description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 43 artículos en NYTimes en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
content:
La palabra del día en inglés Esta palabra ha aparecido en 43 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase? 22 de agosto de 2025 a las

: a 20th century system of Russian camps where political prisoners were sent to do forced labor

: sistema de campos rusos del siglo XX donde se enviaba a los presos políticos a realizar trabajos forzados El término gulag equivale en español a gulag. Recuerda que las palabras de un idioma no siempre tienen una correspondencia directa en otro idioma. Esto es, a veces es necesario usar una frase para expresar el significado de un término en otro idioma. Igualmente, pueden no compartir todos sus significados. La palabra gulag ha aparecido en 43 artículos de NYTimes.com en el último año, incluido el 11 de junio en “How a D.C. Prep-School Kid Became Hollywood’s Most Dependable Bruiser”, de Irina Aleksander. El artículo trata del actor Jon Bernthal, quien fue a Moscú en 1999 para estudiar su oficio: Russian theater, meanwhile, was like a military school for Bernthal. His teachers had staged unsanctioned plays during the Soviet era, risking imprisonment and the gulag. One of them feigned insanity and was confined to a mental institution for three years. Theater represented real danger — real anarchy. It was something they were willing to die for. ¿Puedes utilizar correctamente la palabra gulag en una frase? A partir de la definición y el ejemplo proporcionados, escribe una frase en inglés con la palabra del día de hoy. Lo más importante es que tu frase tenga sentido y demuestre que entiendes la definición de la palabra, pero también te animamos a que seas creativo y te diviertas. Para tener una mejor idea de cómo se puede utilizar gulag en una frase, lee estos ejemplos de uso en Vocabulary.com. También puedes visitar esta guía y aprender a utilizar los símbolos IPA que muestran cómo se pronuncian las distintas palabras. Si disfrutas con este reto, prueba nuestros cuestionarios de vocabulario. La palabra del día la proporciona Vocabulary.com. Obtén más información y consulta ejemplos de uso sobre diversos temas en el Diccionario Vocabulary.com. En esta columna encontrarás todas las ediciones de la Palabra del día.

The word of the day in English this word has appeared in 43 articles at Nytimes.com in the last year. Can you use it in a sentence? August 22, 2025 at

: A 20th Century System of Russian Camps where Political Prisoners were feel forced work

: Russian field system of the twentieth century where political prisoners were sent to make forced labor the term Gulag is equivalent to Gulag in Spanish. Remember that the words of a language do not always have a direct correspondence in another language. This is sometimes it is necessary to use a phrase to express the meaning of one term in another language. Likewise, they may not share all their meanings. The word Gulag has appeared in 43 articles by Nytimes.com in the last year, including June 11 in “How A D.C. Prep-School Kid Became Hollywood’s Most dependable Bruiser”, by Irina Aleksander. The article is about actor Jon Bernthal, who went to Moscow in 1999 to study his trade: Russian Theater, Meanwhile, was like to Military School for Bernthal. His Teachers Had Staged Unsanctinated Plays During the Soviet Era, Risking Imprisonment and the Gulag. One of Them Feigned Insanity and Was Confined to a Mental Institution for Three Years. Theater Represented Real Danger - Real Anarchy. It was submissions they were Willing to die for. Can you correctly use the word gulag in a sentence? From the definition and the example provided, write a phrase in English with the word of today. The most important thing is that your phrase makes sense and show that you understand the definition of the word, but we also encourage you to be creative and have fun. To have a better idea of ​​how Gulag can be used in a phrase, read these examples of use in vocabulary.com. You can also visit this guide and learn to use the IPA symbols that show how the different words are pronounced. If you enjoy this challenge, try our vocabulary questionnaires. The word of the day provides vocabulary.com. Get more information and consult examples of use on various topics in the vocabular and.com dictionary. In this column you will find all the editions of the word of the day.

translatedSummary: The word of the day in English has been the subject of numerous articles at Nytimes.com, including the word "gulishly", which has appeared in 43 articles in the past year. The challenge involves using the word in a sentence that expresses the meaning of a term in another language, such as "gulp", or "gurish", to express the meaning in different languages. The most important thing is making sense and demonstrating that you understand the definition of the word. To learn more about how to use the term in different ways, read these examples of use in vocabulary.

argos_summary: The word of the day is 'gulag,' referring to a 20th-century system of Russian labor camps for political prisoners. It has appeared in 43 articles on NYTimes.com over the past year, including a piece about actor Jon Bernthal's experiences in Moscow. The article highlights the dangers faced by theater practitioners during the Soviet era, where risking imprisonment and gulag was a reality.
